G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 97.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 97, as Plaintiff seeks monetary damages under state law arising from Defendant’s breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 2 and 8.proposition: Venue is proper in Cambridge District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 2 and 8, as the Plaintiff resides at the subject property, which is located in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential lease in Massachusetts includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, which guarantees tenants the right to peaceful enjoyment of their rental property without substantial interference by their landlord, anyone acting on the landlord’s behalf, or other circumstances stemming from the landlord’s actions.

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mas.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)*
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mas.proposition: Under Massachusetts statutory and common law, a landlord may be held liable for interfering with the enjoyment of the premises even if the interference is not malicious or done in bad faith.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mas.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mas.support_reasoning: The court’s discussion of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 makes clear that landlord liability does not turn on malice or bad faith, but on whether serious interference with the tenancy is the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s acts or omissions. The court expressly states that the landlord’s intentions are irrelevant and that liability may arise from failures to act (e.g., failing to take reasonable measures to remove dangerous nontenants), which aligns with the proposition that interference need not be malicious or in bad faith. Thus, the case supports the claimed principle under Massachusetts statutory and common law of quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy… In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716 (1977). Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’”

*Al Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: Under Massachusetts statutory and common law, a landlord may be held liable for interfering with the enjoyment of the premises even if the interference is not malicious or done in bad faith.
*Al Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The court explicitly explains that the 1973 revision of G.L. c. 186, § 14 eliminated the prior requirement of intentional conduct and that liability may be based on negligent (or reckless) conduct involving “some degree of fault.” Thus, the landlord can be liable for interfering with quiet enjoyment without malicious or bad‑faith intent, so long as at least negligence is shown. The opinion clarifies that strict liability without fault is not enough, but it clearly rejects any requirement of malice or bad faith.
*Al Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: At common law, and as originally enacted by statute, the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibited a landlord from wilful or intentional interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises. In 1973, the statute was rewritten and the requirement of intentional conduct was eliminated; landlords could now be held liable for “directly or indirectly” interfering with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises. … we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless … and we concluded that negligent conduct… could support the imposition of liability under § 14.

*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that significant construction noise and related conditions can violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion addresses only defective conditions inside the unit (e.g., leaks, ants, appliances) and whether they breached the warranty of habitability or covenant of quiet enjoyment. It does not discuss construction noise or related construction conditions at all, nor does it articulate any rule that such noise can violate quiet enjoyment. Instead, the court finds no interference with quiet enjoyment on these facts, so this case does not support the claimed proposition about construction noise.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. … Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions. … The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102-03.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that significant construction noise and related conditions can violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102-03.support_reasoning: The case involves flooding, sewage, and unsanitary conditions in a basement apartment, not construction noise or anything analogous. The court’s quiet enjoyment discussion focuses on sewage flooding as an interference and on the statutory framework of G.L. c. 186, § 14; it nowhere addresses construction activity or noise as a basis for violating the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, citing this case for the specific proposition about significant construction noise is inaccurate.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102-03.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977). Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.proposition: Defendant’s failure to adequately mitigate the construction noise and dust also represents negligent management of the property and constitutes “serious interference” as defined by Massachusetts law.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.support_reasoning: The case addresses constructive eviction and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment due to excessive noise from a lounge the landlord could control, not construction noise and dust or a generalized duty to mitigate such conditions. The court focuses on the landlord’s responsibility for objectionable noise created by a commercial tenant and the resulting loss of habitability, but it does not discuss negligent management of construction or define “serious interference” in the broader way asserted. Thus, relying on Blackett for the specific proposition about construction noise/dust and negligent management misstates its holding.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge… we decline to perpetuate that distinction where the landlord creates a situation and has the right to control the objectionable conditions.”
